While not at all relevent to what I was searching for, your post was interesting enough for me to not click back right away. Just wanted to comment before leaving to let you know that the internet is a weird place and you are getting visitors from places I'll bet you never thought possible. Thanks.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
At The Compound facilities you will find a perfect mix of old school training techniques, innovative, creative workout equipment and classes. We also have a diverse boxing, kickboxing, Jiu Jitsu, wrestling and MMA program. Women, men, and kids, regardless,  if you're training to win the next Cross Fit games, the Olympics or just shed that belly fat for the swimsuit you love so much, The Compound was developed just for you. If you're trying to be the next UFC or WBO world champ or just want to learn some fighting and self defense skills, The Compound is where you need to be.

Focusing on sports and excercise science, as well as the time tested traditions and fundamentals of martial arts we are constantly adding in our own little bit of Compound flavor. We have truly figured out the most effective, affordable, fun, and enjoyable training experiences you will ever have. It's nice to know that for a certain part of your day you can come to The Compound and be trained by the best coaches in the world at the most trend-setting, futuristic, yet traditional, highly respected gym...The Compound.

With well over 150 combined years of coaching and teaching experience, The Compound staff is really second to none. Any Compound location that you choose to visit will certainly provide the same quality instruction as well as maintaining the quality of the  training facility. Each location will cater to the demographic of it's locale, adding it's own independent flavor, while maintaining the high expectations of a Compound Training Center.

At The Compound, we train like it matters. So if you have that pro boxing debut coming up, gotta lose 15 pounds before your wedding photos, or really want that Jiu Jitsu black belt, this is the place for you. So, undefeated fighters, soccer moms and dads come join the movement. Join The Compound!

item.title: Jiu Jitsu
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Jiu Jitsu: Taught by Sean Loeffler. A history lesson about the origins and methods that is necessary to be educated and victorious in the cutthroat Gi Jiu Jitsu world. Sean has spent more than half of his life studying the art of Brazilian Jiu Jitsu under Bob Bass (the 1st American Black Belt under the “Machado” brothers as well as the 1995 world champion). Due to the fact that his mentor is commonly referred to as the most technical black belt of the “Dirty Dozen” (the 1st, 12 non Brazilians to ever earn the rank of black belt in the sport) it’s needless to say that Loeffler has perfected the art of the clear-cut Gi Jiu Jitsu victory! In his life, Sean has traveled the world to perfect his ground game and has been taught by some of the highest profile top instructors in the history of the sport. This class is practiced in the traditional Jiu Jitsu Gi uniform and the structure is unique and challenging. The students have verified the program by placing very well in high level competitions. This system is tried and confirmed: if you want to become a member of the elite ground game community take part in this course.

item.title: Boxing
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: BOXING FUNDAMENTALS: Taught by Rene Mendez. This class teaches the rudiments of traditional boxing. Students will master the different aspects of boxing including footwork, angles, head movement, as well as delivering plethoras of powerful punches. Sparring is encouraged and is also very well supervised by our professional coaches. Boxing is a timeless art and the utilization of the sweet science is vital for anyone who wants to fight and become a future champion pugilist.

item.title: Muay Tai
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: MUAY THAI KICKBOXING: Taught by Brodie Farber. This class teaches the basic, advanced, as well as the finer points of Thai boxing. Students will not only learn proper striking, kicking and use of elbows and knees, but also the more productive ways of working in the clinch. Brodie has traveled consistently to Thailand for more than a decade to polish his skills and effectiveness as an instructor. Fighting in the UFC as well as in Thailand Farber has competed at the highest level the sport has to offer and his experiences will translate into your growth as a stand up fighter. You dont have to be a fighter to take this class, but you do have to take this class if you want to be a fighter.

item.title: Sean Loeffler
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sean Loeffler is currently signed to the UFC. Sean has been training and competing in martial arts since he was 5 years old.He hold black belts in Tae Kwon Do and Tang Su Do as well as a brown belt in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu under Bob Bass (Machado's first ever American black belt). Sean has also competed successfully in wrestling, BJJ and amateur boxing tournaments, and is a 7 time Mixed Martial Arts World Champion. With a professional fight record of 25-5, he is an innovative and skilled grappler/fighter with a motivating and extremely effective teaching style.

item.title: Class Descriptions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Please see Navigation bar on the left

item.title: Strength & Conditioning
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Strength and conditioning, this class is taught by Andy Schnadig, the creator of "Holistic Performance". Old school training needs modern exercise science. Andy's workouts are the meat and potatoes of high intensity endurance training. Classes encompass all aspects of activities involving the human body: including flexibility. explosion, agility, core strength, balance, power and stamina. This intense workout puts other workouts to shame. The vigorous pace is maintained throughout the entire hour with internals and various types of innovative and ground-breaking movements and drills. The results are undeniable and you will truly feel a sense of accomplishment after participating in one of Andy's one of a kind Strength and Conditioning workouts!

item.title: Combat Fit
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Combat Fit, this is taught by Steve Kozola. This class is for the individual that enjoys hard cardio combined with the striking of combat sports. There is no sparring in this class, but you'll feel like you've been in the ring for a championship fight after you've completed the workout. The practice will sometimes involve partnering up on kicking shields, focus mitts, Thai pads and punching bags. It's always fun to mix up your training schedule and hit something while doing it! Always challenging, always sweating, and always smiling, this session will make you feel like a fighter but without getting punched or kicked in the face. You won't get beat up but you will feel like it after 60 minutes of Steve's Combat Fit.

item.title: Submission Grappling
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Submission Grappling, this is taught by Sean Loeffler. This is a unique and revolutionary system that teaches unorthodox and traditional techniques in submission grappling. It is sound grappling techniques coupled with the philosophy that makes it a proven success in competition. Not only will the students practice grappling methods from Jiu Jitsu, Sambo, Catch Wrestling, Judo and many more tactical ground fighting systems. But Sean Loeffler has also invented some of the most aggressive yet high percentage ways of "grabbing" that fight ending submission from positions the grappling community has never seen before. Guaranteed to please the avid ground fighter or the first time practitioner. Submission grappling will become a vital part of your fight training.

item.title: Wrestling
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Wrestling, This is taught by Eddie Escobar. This class teaches the basic wrestling techiniques needed to be  successful in the complex world of MMA or the realm of competitive wrestling at ANY level. Take down techniques, avoiding and preventing the take down, transitions and domination of the opponent. Wrestling may be the most important martial art of all due to the fact that the superior wrestler dictates where the match takes place: standing or on the mat. An essential for anyone that wants to compete in MMA or wrestling whether it's at the amateur or pro level.

item.title: MMA
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: MMA, Taught by Sean Loeffler. Mixed Martial Arts is a class that teaches unconventional as well as conventional fighting forms and is unique to The Compound. For those who train in the striking or grappling arts these techniques will help further develop those skills and create personal sucess in your comabt sports abilities. Not only will the MMA practice define and improve your all around athleticism and success as a martial artist, but you will also be handed the concepts and tools that are essential to become a top level fighter. Sean has create a sure fire way to finish and control the entirety of a fight from start to finish. This class involves sparring, drilling and evensoe note taking as well as technique to mold you into an unstoppable force!

item.title: Andy Schnadig
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Andy has been a trainer since 1999 and holds multiple certifications in a wide variety of specialties. His certifications and training have included ACE, ISSA, IFA, the CHEK Institute, HHP, NMT and Russian Kettlebell Challenge. Over the years, he has trained equestrian riders to Pro MMA fighters to soccer-moms to collegiate All-Americans and everything in between, specializing in corrective exercise and combative athletes ie.. wrestlers, football players, boxers, Muay Thai, MMA etc... He has experience training and cornering fighters in UFC, Bellator and a host of smaller shows. Andy holds a Purple Belt in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and has trained in Muay Thai both here and in Thailand

item.title: News
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Latest News
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to Zach Willms on his decisive win in Gladiator Challenge at Soboba Casino this past Saturday. He is now 4-1 pro at 145lbs. He fought a tough guy, but his well-rounded training and the fact that he listened to his corner secured the "W"! Watch for yourselves...

 

 

http://youtu.be/GJ2onYR7B-0

 

 

The women of The Compound participated yesterday in this awesome event that raises money for Autism research. We had a great time! We were challenged by the obstacles, the uphill trail running and most of all by the heat...it was 113 degrees out in Barona yesterday at the site of the event! We're a bit scuffed up but because of the training we do at The Compound we felt confident that we'd finish the course and we did so completing every obstacle. Thanks Compound for getting us in Gladiator shape!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The beautiful Crystal Garcia did a great job at the 2013 NPC World Bodybuilding Champoinships in June. Crystal has a rockin' bod that she keeps in competition shape at The Compound!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The Legendary and I mean truly legendary Bob Bass was at the Compound in June teaching amazing jiu jitsu in a special  free seminar open to all Compound members. The man is a jiu jitsu genius! The techniques he showed elevated everyone's game. Even his protoge and long time pupil, Sean Loeffler, was amazed at what he learned that day! A great time was had by all and The Compound is truly honored to take up the mantle and continue the name of Bob Bass.

 

 

 

 

Another win for

 

The Compound! Wayne "Problem King" Phillips racked up another win, his fourth in a row, at Epic Fighting in San Diego this past friday night.Wayne is a real up-and-comer!

item.title: Upcoming Events
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
5 YEAR ANNIVERSARY BEACH BASH!

Saturday, July 14th at the Oceanside Harbor Beach covered patio area. We are hosting this party to thank our members and their families for their loyalty to The Compound. We know that it is because of our members that we are a successful gym and because of our staff that we are the best MMA training center in San Diego County. Our members and their families are welcome to come out to the beach and have some fun. There will be a barbecue, so just bring a side dish to share and whatever you want to drink. Sign up in the office...we need a head count. Bring your beach toys and help us celebrate our 5 year anniversary!

item.title: Directions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[google-maps width=675 height=300]

 

From San Clemente: Take 5 Fwy South and exit Oceanside Blvd. Head east about 4 miles and turn left on Corporate Center. Turn right on the first street, Oceanic Drive. Continue on about 100 yards and turn right into the first driveway. You'll find us as soon as you enter.

From San Diego: Take 5 Fwy North and exit Oceanside Blvd. Head east about 4 miles and turn left on Corporate Center. Turn right on the first street, Oceanic Drive. Continue on about 100 yards and turn right into the first driveway. You'll find us as soon as you enter.

item.title: Kid's MMA
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: <strong> Kid's MMA teaches all the basics of MMA including wrestling, striking, submission grappling and fitness. These classes build self-esteem and confidence. Kids with self-confidence are less likely to suffer bullying at school. We stress discipline and self-control while teaching all these critical elements of self-defense. All this in a fun, family environment. Kids MMA is open to boys and girls ages 7-14.<strong/>

Come on down, save some money and get the quality gear you need.

item.title: John Schultes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: John started Muay Thai in 1994 at Black Tiger ,San Diego’s first Muay Thai Gym. In 1996 John moved to world champion Melchor Menor’s gym.Then in 1997 John moved to Los Angles and started training at Muay Thai Academy in North Hollywood . He trained under Kru Puk, Saekson Janjira and the legendary Coban Lookchaomaesaithong. After Coban Lookchaomaesaithong and then Saekson Janjira left MTA John trained under coach Pong. He now enjoys teaching what he’s been lucky enough to learn from some of the best trainers in the world.

item.title: Big Weekend for Compound Fighters
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
I'm in Kansas City, Missouri to Corner Compound Fighter, Eddie Sanchez as he takes on Brett Rogers in the main event for Titan Fighting Championships.


You may have seen Eddie in the gym sparring or doing his Strength and Conditioning. He looks and feels good and is prepared to put a whooping on Brett!  

Watch it live on HD Net tonite @ 7pm pst. Check out his incredibly sexy corner man when you tune in! See you all on Monday!

item.title: Big Weekend for Compound Fighters part 2
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded: Our recently departed Muay Thai coach, Brodie Farber, will be showcasing his Muay thai skills this weekend on Friday Night Fights in NY City.

item.title: Finally this weekend in San Diego
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded: Our very own MMA and grappling coach, Sean Loeffler, will be fighting on Camp Pendelton with a slew of other compound fighters including, Jared, Wayne, Brandon, and more! This event is local so come out and support your local Compound Fighter.

item.title: Thailand Bitches!
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
So there is a travel warning put out by the US government not to travel to Thailand unless absolutely necessary. The flight to Bangkok is 18 hours. Thats right, 18 straight hours on a plane. But we are going anyway!!!
 

See you guys in a couple weeks. We get back just in time for the Halloween Party at the gym Saturday October 29th at 7pm.


Stay tuned to Facebook and this blog for updates on our adventure.
The next trip is in the spring during the last week of March and the first week of April. Start saving now

item.title: slider 1
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Training gone crazy!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: For the past couple of weeks, Andy and Alan have really been turning up the insanity of the strength and conditioning classes. I've had to push myself harder than ever before and we've been doing insane things like dragging weighted tires around the building! Some days have been hard to get through, but I feel stronger and my cardio is better. Thanks guys. You rock!

item.title: Big Weekend for Compound Fighters!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Compound mopped up yesterday in competition! We had two kids,  Ethan Frantz and Malcolm MacClaren,  both won 1st place in their weight classes at GrapplingX Pankration tourny at The Fight Lab in Murrieta. This was their first Pankration tourny and they both did great. We are super proud! Then our guys were at the Armed Forces MMA Championship on Camp Pendleton and cleaned house! Brandon Collins won 1st in both Pankration and Grappling at 205. Nick Kaluza won 1st in Pankration at 135. Jered Lowe won 3rd in Grappling at heavyweight, Ross Blue won 3 in grappling at 155. These guys represent The Compound with pride and The Compound is proud to have them fight under our banner. Good job guys!

item.title: Steve Kozola
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Steve has a Bachelor of Science degree from Northern Illinois University in Kinesiology and Exercise Science. He has trained professional athletes including UFC fighters, professional football, basketball and baseball players and pro boxers. He has a winning record as an amateur mma fighter and kickboxer. He holds a black belt in Tae Kwon Do and a blue belt in BJJ.

He is a very hands on trainer with an energetic and motivating style. His class will push you to be better than you were yesterday...gotta love it!

item.title: Jon Rizo
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Jon “The Brick” Rizo was born in El Paso, Texas but raised in Los Angeles, CA.  Jon credits boxing with saving his life and keeping him on the right track. He got into trouble as a kid, but soon found boxing to be his outlet.  Stepped into the ring for the first time in Vista and soon had an amateur record of 10 wins by 1st round knockout. Eventually he went pro and had a record of 3 wins by 1st round knockout.  He trained under the late great Hector Gil until his tragic death . Jon trains religiously 6 days a week and is a phenomenal boxing coach. He is a forceful advocate for families and children, believes that boxing is a way to get healthy and fit. He aspires to be the next boxing heavyweight champion .

item.title: Eddie Escobar
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Eddie Escobar was born and raised in Illinois, the heartland of USA wrestling. He has been wrestling for over 15 years under many great coaches. Eddie wrestled for Martinez Elite Wrestling Club from the age of 10-14, under Jose Martinez and his sons Nathen and Izzy Martinez (wrestling coach for UFC Champion Jon “Bones” Jones). While at Martinez Elite, Eddie was a part of 3 back-back-back state championship teams. In high school Eddie was a varsity starter all 4 years and team captain his latter 2 years at Plainfield South High School. He also wrestled year around competing in Freestyle and Greco Roman wrestling tournaments. During the summers he travelled to many universities to train in the off season such as University of Michigan, Northern Illinois University, and North Central College. While in high school Eddie organized and ran many summer wrestling camps for kids ranging 6-12 years of age during his down time. Upon graduating high school Eddie attended Northern Illinois University where he walked on to the wrestling team and while earning his Bachelors of Arts. His wrestling career came to an end after 2 seasons at NIU to become the assistant varsity coach at Plainfield South High School. Soon after Eddie became the interim head wrestling coach at Plainfield North High School at the age of 20. In the summer of 2011 Eddie began training at a local MMA gym where he attended university, where he trained under 2x Division 1 Wrestling National Champion Shawn Jackson. Under Shawn Jackson Eddie went 3-2 as a MMA fighter, and took first place in both gi and no-gi division at USA Grappling tournament. Upon Coach Jacksons departure to California, Eddie became the head instructor at United MMA. He lead many fight camps using a wrestling based curriculum to lead many fighters to title wins. While at United MMA, Eddie’s team racked up 6 title belts and countless wins. Eddie currently holds a BJJ rank of Blue belt, earning it only months after starting and looks to continue his studies as grappler, while also encourage others to further their skills to become champions.

item.title: Mike (MROC) Confer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Mike 'MROC' Confer is a CrossFit Level 1 Trainer, NASM Performance Enhancement Specialist, and former Marine Martial Arts Instructor.  He has been racing competitively since 2011 and is eager to share his passion for OCR (Obstacle Course Racing) with veterans and rookies alike.  Mike has a creative and fun approach to training where he provides a challenging team environment where his members can workout side-by-side without fear of being judged or intimidated.

item.title: Dr. Shaun Blake, DPT
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Shaun Blake DPT

Shaun has been involved in Fitness and competitive sports for the past 10 years.  He has a Bachelors Degree in Kinesiology with an emphasis is exercise physiology and applied exercise science.  He furthered his education by getting his Doctorate in Physical Therapy. 

He has played Division 1 baseball, competed at the professional level for Triathlon, and is an avid baseball, football, and weight lifter.  His passion is in optimizing individual’s performance through exercise and nutrition. 

Shaun is one of The Compound’s Strength and Conditioning coaches.  If you’re looking for a comprehensive strength and conditioning program then he is the man.  Come in and try class...get stronger, more agile, improve your endurance.

.

item.title: Whatever happened to showing up and actually fighting?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Let me start by saying that I am a huge Clay Guida fan. I think the guy has phenomenal skills and crazy cardio. That said, why didn't he fight? He danced around and jumped around and bobbed and weaved like no other, the entire time in the cage...but he didn't fight. He didn't fight like we've seen him fight so many times in the past. His,  have been some of the most exciting fights in the UFC for years. What happened?


It seems that he's been infected by the same bug as all the other exciting fighters that start training at Greg Jackson's camp. It must be Jackson's "go-to" game plan to have his fighters stall and go the distance. Are the sponsors paying him by the televised minute? Don't the sponsors want to see great fights? As much as I love GSP, he's suffering from the same ailment. They're all about playing it safe and lasting the entire fight instead of going in there in fighting to win. Come on fellas, sometimes you'll lose, but you'll give the fans (and the sponsors) what they want...an exciting fight. When you do that, the UFC is happy cuz people will pay for pay-per-view to watch you if your exciting.


I long for the days of old...when fighters actually fought.

item.title: Brandon Vera vs. Shogun
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Actually, a great night of fights, last night on UFC on Fox card. Brandon Vera put on his best performance in years. He fought like he used to years ago...there was this fire in his eyes. He fought hard,  which showed Shogun maximum respect. He fought unbreakably, which shows the fans maximum respect.


It looks like Brandon Vera is BACK! His fans are elated. The UFC is happy. We can all get excited about the next Brandon Vera fight, because it's gonna be better than last night's fight for sure!

item.title: Breakdown UFC 154: Georges St. Pierre Vs. Carlos Condit
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This week, owner of The Compound Sean Loeffler, will give his personal analysis of this weekends upcoming UFC event that is headlining George St. Pierre vs Carlos Condit:

I am very excited for this Saturday's UFC event for the undisputed world welterweight championship...BUT, I am excited for every reason that you probably are not....and definitely NOT interested in the main event due to the fact that G.S.P., as of recent years, has only put together a few lack luster, boring, yet dominant performances verses other lack luster boring, yet dominant fighters. This sucks because he used to be so exciting...his nickname was “Rush”....now its more like “Rest”...while on top of another dude. On the opposite site of the octagon will stand the lanky somewhat muscular Carlos Condit...formally “The Natural Born Killer”...as of late,”The Running man or poster boy for Adidas”, complete disengaging from real exchanges and poking, prodding, and avoiding any real confrontation while backing up the entire fight....SO before I tell you why I am truly excited for this event ill give my quick breakdown of this particular fight.

GSP is too strong and athletic for Condit. His wrestling and strength will dictate takedowns and ground control, as well as top position damage. There will not be a finish in this fight due to the fact that both fighters have worked with each others coaches and camps extensively and will have enough insight to prevent them from being able to finish each other. ANOTHER, boring 5 round wrestle fest with a few decent exchanges, maybe a knockdown or two, a few threatened subs and a 49-46 GSP unanimous decision win.

Now, the reason why I am excited and its pretty damn simple: The Undercard is unreal. Another set of welterweights colliding this night will be Kampman vs Hendricks, and a possible future title contender will be decided by this match. In other action “Dirty” Tom Lawler vs Francis Carmot, another Tri-Star fighter from St. Pierre's gym has looked to be the real deal and this will be a real test. Yet, another middleweight main card fight puts Nick Ring against Striker Constantinos Phillipou. If that wasn't enough for me there are two other middleweight bouts on the card, my division. So, its a very personal card due to the fact that the top rankings in the middleweight and welterweight divisions could potentially be turned on its head in one night...awesome. Lets get it on!

item.title: Kush and CBass Win At XFS
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This past weekend, compound fighters Kush and Cbass earned TKO wins at Xplode Fight Series.

Kush, a heavyweight, was dominant from the opening bell and landed blow after blow to his opponent and ended the fight before the the first minute. This was Kush's first MMA fight and if this fight is any indication of his future performance then the heavyweight division needs to brace themselves.

item.title: Chris Black Kicks Off String Of Victories
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This has been an epic month of fighting for The Compound. It started with the final amatuer win for Chris Black before he moves up to the professional level.  His tough fought decision win set the stage for a month that would be full of Compound victories.

Chris was clearly dominant throughout the fight and the decision was no surprise to the crowd.  His opponent was game though and took multiple hard shots without getting knocked down, although everyone in attendance though it would happen.

As one of the Compound fight teams longest continuous members, Chris took the lead and set the pace for the rest of the team, which has racked up wins in every fight promotion in the San Diego area.  This month will be capped by a title fight with Wayne "Problem King" Phillips at Epic Fighting this Friday, March 29th, so don't miss that upcoming win either!

item.title: Nick Kaluza Is Ready for War!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Nick Kaluza fights tomorrow with a 10-3 amatuer record as well as being the Epic Fighting World Bantam Weight Champion.  Nick is on a five fight win streak and tomorrow, Sunday, June 30th at Soboba Casino in San Jacinto, CA he finally makes his long awaited, much anticipated professional debut, in the Gladiator Challenge promotion.

Fighting out of The Compound  in North County San Diego, Nick has been trained by UFC and Bellator veterans, Sean Loeffler and Joey Beltran, as well as working with Jiu Jitsu Legend and first American Black belt,  Bob Bass.  Nick has also been training with world renowned strength and conditioning coach, Steve Kozola, who was the conditioning Coach for Ultimate Fighter winners and UFC veterans, Stephan Bonner and Amir Sadollah.

Aside from his stellar Coaching and MMA credentials, Nick was a stand out Michigan high school wrestler and again he wrestled in college at Marion Military Institute.  He was the 2010 California State no gi grappling champion and the 2011-2012 National Pankration Champion.  Nick is well on his way to being the next "little big thing"!

For more information, sponsorship and booking contact www.TheCompoundMMA.com

item.title: The Top 5 Richest MMA Fighters
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
These are the five most successful fighters in all of MMA and the richest too!

#1. has an estimated net worth of $20 million. Much of it comes from being one of only two UFC champions in two different weight classes, as well as his stint on the successful reality TV show The Ultimate Fighter. However, much of his wealth is also owed to his family’s fortune.

#2. Tito Ortiz has an estimated net worth of $15 million. His millions come from a career stretching back to 1997 fighting in the UFC, capturing the light heavyweight crown early on and defending it a record five times. His fortune also comes from his business acumen, having established a successful clothing brand with Punishment Athletics.

#3. Randy Couture has an estimated net worth of $14 million. Randy has fought in the UFC for most of his career but also has starred in several movies, most notably as a member of the Expendables franchise, he also owns his own clothing line as well as a gym in Las Vegas.

#4. Chuck Liddell has an estimated net worth of $13 million. Chuck's money came from 23 fights in the UFC and six outside it. he also starred in several movies as well as popular reality TV shows like The Ultimate Fighter and Dancing with the Stars.

#5. Brock Lesnar has an estimated net worth of $12.5 million. Most of his wealth has come from his time as a professional wrestler for the WWE, where he’s held the championship belt three times.

item.title: Top 5 MMA Stare Downs
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
There is nothing quite like a good old MMA stare down. It’s enthralling to watch the pair that are about to enter the cage get in touch with their barbaric sides, mentally. It fills the audience with anticipation like nothing else can.

  1. The Ultimate Fighter 9 Finale: Diego Sanchez vs. Clay Guida. The stare down itself was worth the price of admission.
  2. UFC 52: Matt Hughes vs. Frank Trigg II. The true dislike that the pair has for each other was evident in the stare down.
  3. UFC 127: Michael Bisping vs. Jorge Rivera. Bisping couldn’t wait to get in Rivera’s face.
  4. UFC 137: BJ Penn vs. Nick Diaz. The stare down was just as intense as the beginning of their third round.
  5. UFC 126: Anderson Silva vs. Vitor Belfort. One would never believe these two were training partners!

item.title: Matt Riddle Retires from MMA
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
Matthew Riddle announced his retirement from mixed martial arts on Monday at the age of 27. Riddle debuted on the national scene on Season 7 of The Ultimate Fighter. This is the scoop so far, Riddle can't fight as scheduled on September 20 because of a cracked rib and that his newest employer, Bellator, can't get him a fight this year. The result is that Riddle cannot afford to train in mixed martial arts anymore.

Is it possible that Riddle could be poor? He was fighting regularly in the UFC and he is so talented, could it be so? His last five fights, which trace back to September 2011, may just reveal the secret. Finding out is not an easy tasking since payouts for international events are generally not released to the public. It’s easy to estimate a fighter's win/show money based on previously reported fights.

 

Date

Event

Opponent

Result

Earnings

Sept. 2011

UFC Fight Night: Shields vs. Ellenberger

Lance Benoist

Loss

$12,000 + $55,000 FOTN Bonus

Feb. 2012

UFC 143

Henry Martinez

Win

$15,000/$15,000

July 2012

UFC 149

Chris Clements

Win

$15,000/$15,000 +$65,000 FOTN Bonus

Nov. 2012

UFC 154

John Maguire

Win

$15,000/$15,000

Feb. 2013

UFC on Fuel: Barao vs. McDonald

Che Mills Win      

Win

$15,000/$15,000

 

The July 2012 and the February 2013 were overturned due to drug test failures for marijuana. Without those two drug test failures, Riddle would have earned approximately $252,000 in 17 months. With the failures, the number drops to $157,000. Riddle would have had to pay due to his status as a contractor from that. That’s a pretty decent salary and is not including a minimum of $25,000 to $50,000 over the duration of the five fights from sponsorships. Riddle should not be so broke that he cannot afford to train and forced into retirement. The numbers just don’t add up.

item.title: Military & Law Enforcement Relying More on MMA
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
There are several military and law enforcement academies that at one point in time were martial arts academies. Military and law enforcement officials use combative & tactical training in the form of MMA for their military, federal, state, and local law enforcement organizations.

Why MMA?

MMA delivers unique one of a kind specialized skills that are often lifesavers in real world operations. This is why the FBI, SWAT, and Federal Air Marshals use MMA for comprehensive development. This is not a new approach to protect those who serve us and it has saved some lives.

These individuals meet up with mighty challenges that require taking immediate action while maintaining reasoning in the worst situations imaginable. Complicating things even farther, this has to be done in seconds. This is why MMA is paramount. It teaches how to respond instinctively.

MMA Enhances Self Discipline

Because MMA is emerging so quickly, it is vital that these individuals stay abreast of what is going on. The self-discipline and perseverance that MMA delivers is unsurpassed. Police departments have taught self-defense techniques for many years now but now the focus is more on Jiu-Jitsu, Aikido, wrestling, and boxing.

More MMA & Fewer Weapons

This is very useful for these individuals to know because it reduces the use of weapons, Tasers, and pepper sprays and it boosts morale. MMA relies on sound ideologies that let a smaller person to control the situation even when the opponent is much bigger or stronger. It allows one to inflict pain, maintain control, and this is crucial for both law enforcement and military personnel because it is based on joint locks, throws and take downs.

The same holds true for the various branches of the military. In fact, in World War 2- they had their own combat system based on simple martial arts techniques. The United States Arm Force uses merciless martial art which combines Taekwondo, power kicking, powerful punching, and Jiu Jutju, Judo, Hapkido for grappling. A very tough, effective and convincing combination.

item.title: Charlie Hunnam Relies on Martial Arts to Stay Fit
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
He is sexy, he is smoking hot and he is 33 year old Charlie Hunnam. He is preparing for his upcoming role as Christian Grey in Fifty Shades of Grey, where he has to be in great shape. His intense workout regimen includes an array of martial arts. While performing in the "Sons of Anarchy" Hunnam was already practicing martial arts and is constantly in the gym.

Mental Clarity

Charlie Hunnam says that he is uncertain if he will employ a trainer for his fitness routine but says he is fanatical with working out but doesn't go to the gym to essentially look good but because it makes him feel good. Hunnam said, "The benefit of working out is 90 percent mental and 10 percent physical. I feel better - like I have more energy. But the mental side is an extraordinary benefit. I'm happier, more confident, and more positive when I work out. And I feel like I'm a better actor because of the clarity it gives me."

Diet & Exercise

Hunnam says even with his hectic schedule he always manages to find time to hit the gym. "I work 15 hours a day and still go to the gym. Most people work eight hours a day and say 'I haven't got time to work out. If you want to be super-fit and look ripped then you find the time no matter what." Hunnam also contributes his fine physique to a clean diet consisting of vegetable juice and natural foods.

Bartendaz

Hunnam started taking up Bartendaz, which is an intense fitness regime created by a group of guys from Harlem and Brooklyn that combines calisthenics, military drills and martial arts. "Working out in the gym, doing the same stuff day in and day out can get boring. What keeps it fresh and fun is free styling moves. I got to the point where I could do three muscle-ups then start adding the flips in between and creating signature stuff."

item.title: Self-Defensive Martial Arts Help Female Sexual Assault Victims
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
Any woman that has been sexually assaulted will likely say that the most difficult thing for her to do was to salvage gaining control of her life again. The aftermath is shocking and most women feel like they have lost control, they are nervous, anxious, and always on guard. More women are now discovering that practicing Aikido, a self-defensive martial art, is giving them back a piece of mind and allowing them to gain control. This can bring a woman to a healthy place in relation to your mind, body, and spirit.

Releases Endorphins

Aikido and martial arts in general releases endorphins and this will increase energy levels and minimize stress and anxiety. This is very important for survivors of sexual abuse who are often plagued with depression and sadness. This type of activity also increases feelings of control while releasing physical tension; it also helps by giving the woman a place to focus all of her rage and anger.

Survivor Testimony

One sexual abuse survivor said, “I’ve been practicing Aikido, a self-defensive martial art, since the fall of 2010. … I felt like I was regaining control over my body and getting comfortable in my skin again. Right after the rape, my mother said something like, ‘I guess all that Aikido didn’t help after all,’ and in many ways, re-devoting me to the art refuted that. … I found this practice ‘purifying.’ It allowed me to really inhabit my body and not feel or think of anything except practicing. It helped me feel like me again—not some damaged or broken version of not-me.”

Encourages Healing

In addition to Aikido, yoga is a way in which survivors have healed themselves in the long struggle after sexual assault. Women often suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder after being assaulted and yoga and martial arts allow women to reconnect with their body again. They are powerful and help healing. This is why fitness and health in general are so important for women who are sexual abuse survivors. It will help women develop a close relationship with their own physical being.

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Kids everywhere are Joining MMA Classes
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
There was a time when mixed martial arts were just a guy thing but things have changed and now it has become very popular with women and children. The US has seen a huge increase in the number of children partaking in the sport. In fact, the Syracuse News reports an estimated 3 million children of both genders and some as young as five years old are involved in MMA.

The reason for the increase in children being attracted to the sport is because it instills self-discipline and teaches kids how to win and lose gracefully and it teaches good sportsmanship. There are those that oppose children in the cage for safety reasons.  

MMA Benefits Kids

MMA does not teach children how to fight or be violent but what it does do is help kids channel that excess energy that they seem to all have. It also helps kids to stay focused and stay fit. There is some really god exercise moves in tae kwon do, kung Fu, and aikido.

ADHD Benefits

Parents with children that have attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are finding great benefits with using MMA, likely because these particular children lack self-control and concentration skills and this is what MMA can enhance. It also encourages goal setting as kids try to advance to new levels.

MMA also teaches kids the true meaning of respect. This is done through the actual art of MMA. Kids must stand still, bow, and take commands. Research has actually indicated that kids engaged in MMA are better students.

By the time a child is six years old; their muscles have developed well enough to be able to handle MMA, according to an article written in Parenting Magazine. There are a number of choices for kids when it comes to MMA and each offers something different and very beneficial.

item.title: Women Adding New Flavor to MMA
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
Everything about MMA and women is starting to change. The UFC launched its flyweight division back in 2012, the women's bantamweights in 2013, and it looks like 2014 just may see a 115-pound women's straw weight division, according to UFC President Dana White. The reason for this is that more people want to watch the women fights. When the women fight, ratings are up 44-percent.

Adding a New Weight Division

This new weight class will be the tenth in UFC history and only the second for the women, so it is pretty significant. When the women's bantamweight division was launched last February at UFC 157 it was more than ever hoped for and drew in nearly half a million pay-per-view purchases. It was Liz Carmouche and former Strikeforce champion Ronda Rousey that led these efforts.

Just to Name a Few

There are many women in the top strawweights division competing for Invicta FC such as champion Carla Esparza, Claudia Gadel, and Felice Herrig. Don’t forget about top-ranked strawweight Jessica Aguilar recently signed with World Series of Fighting.

Full Speed Ahead: Holly Holm

At the UFC 166 last month, undefeated bantamweight Holly Holm, sure made a strong presence. UFC President Dana White called her a female Conor McGregor and is committed to keeping a keen eye on her. Holm is a former world champion boxer, she has expert kicking skills for which she has competed, she holds a 5-0 record, and is genius in controlling the distance and tempo in her game. She has the talent to be one of the top female fighters in the sport. Holm has had three MMA fights and a boxing match in 2013 is returning to the regional scene this December against Angela Hayes who carries a 6-6 record into the cage. Promoters have been unable to allow Holm to showcase her skills so she will continue on with a few more fights where she is the overwhelming favorite. Maybe this will convince UFC matchmaker Sean Shelby that Holm is prepared to contend with the best in the world.

How Things Change

Just a couple years ago it was believed that there would never be female fighters in the octagon but that was pre Ronda Rousey, the women’s bantamweight champ. Rousey is now an international celebrity and a top draw for the UFC. The co-main event at UFC 168 in December will be Miesha Tate and Ronda Rousey.

item.title: Oscar Patrick Kush Wins Again!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Oscar Patrick Kush showed up at XFS Feast or Famine with bad intentions. He trained hard, cut weight and gave the crowd a short but explosive demonstration of skill and strength. He man-handled his opponent, throwing him around the cage and punishing him with strikes. Oscar is a force to be reckoned with.

http://youtu.be/_-a2NweecU4

item.title: MMA: A Look Ahead into 2014
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
MMA fans get ready because 2014 is going to have some awe-inspiring action for fans! According to an article in the MMA Corner, the year ahead is going to be filled with breathtaking rematches that will be so close that no fan will dare try. This is true for just about every weight division so fans are sure to see their favorites in the cage. It is very possible that the very best fight ever could come down in 2014. Real talk.

MMA Closes out 2013

The first rematch is in the flyweight division and it is in mid-December (14). Demetrious Johnson will attempt to defend his title against Joseph Benavidez after an awkward split decision went in favor of Johnson more than a year ago. This crowned Johnson the first UFC flyweight champion, a title he holds dear. Both have enhanced their sparring skills since so the sky is the limit.

December 28th, Chris Weidman steps into the Octagon for the first time as a defending champion against Anderson Silva in this middleweight rematch. Many called Weidman’s victory a stroke of luck but he is coming back strong to prove neigh Sayers wrong.

MMA Possibilities

At a point which is yet to be determined, there is a real possibility that Anderson Silva and Vitor Belfort could meet again. Silva stopped Belfort with a front kick to the face at UFC 126 and remained middleweight champ.

MMA Females

Look forward to seeing the queen of MMA, Ronda Rousey face off with Miesha Tate, once again. Tate has rallied support from her fans after being on the Ultimate Fighter reality show so now she has a following. She wants to come back and claim what is hers.

Don’t be shocked to see a Jon Jones rematch against Alexander Gustafsson after a close and much scrutinized call the last time they met. Just a few days ago there was the makings for another great rematch between Johny Hendricks and Georges St-Pierre. Fans squelched for the victory to go to Hendricks but it didn’t happen…this time at least.

item.title: Compound Fighter Fernan Ricalday at XFS 11/16/2013

item.title: Huge Rematch this Month: Silva vs. Weidman
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
On December 28, just a few weeks away, in Las Vegas, Anderson Silva and Chris Weidman will go at it once again in one of the biggest rematches in the history of the UFC. Anderson Silva is going to try to win back his middleweight title that Weidman stole from him inside the Octagon at UFC 162.


Learn from Past Mistakes


As Silva looks back at that fight he is trying to recall his mistakes and learn from then to win the rematch. He says the mistakes were pretty basic. Silva said, "My mistakes in that fight, and that’s the first time I’m saying this, were basic mistakes I did everything I had to do except hit him. I didn’t counterattack. When I stopped with my feet parallel, I should have hit him and walked one step behind. I didn’t do that. I saw my mistakes and I’m working on that to train for this next fight."


Silva Says


Brazilian born, Anderson Silva won 16 previous fights under the UFC banner with 14 finishes and says that is how the upcoming fight in the 28th is going to end too. Silva says, "It’s going to be a tough fight and it won’t last too long if it stays standing." Weidman doesn’t expect the upcoming rematch to be an easy win.


Weidman Says


Weidman said this about the fight, "I wish I could sit back and relax and I feel like I’ve accomplished my goal, but I gotta win this next fight bad. Every fight just feels like it's the life changer, feels like the most important fight of your life, and we're still there. This next fight is huge for me, I gotta win."


Another UFC Rematch


But…UFC fans, if December 28th is too far away and you just cannot wait then tune in to the rematch of flyweight champion Demetrious Johnson against Joseph Benavidez. This is going to be a mixed martial arts dream. The event will take place at the Sleep Train Arena in Sacramento, California on Saturday, Dec. 14 at 8 p.m. ET and it will air on FOX.

item.title: Boy/Girl Fighting in MMA? Not a Chance
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
On December 20, 2013, for the first time in history, it was going to be ok for a man to get physical with a woman, and yes, even hit her. In fact, he hoped to knock her right out while the world watched live. Rio de Janeiro set the location for Shooto 45 pro-fighters Emerson Falcao to take on Juliana Velasquez in a legit, full force MMA battle. This promised to be an epic display! There were only two rules: no elbows and no knees.

Giving it Their All


A representative for the fight said that this was the real deal and neither fighter planned on holding back. Falcao said he has no problem sparring with a woman. He said, in an interview with TMZ, "I’ve been training just the same as if I was fighting a man – and I’m going for the knockout."

Another Perspective


Velasquez doesn’t get why people are freaking out but gave her word, "I will win, because I always train with men, there will be no surprises for me.” UFC owner Dana White says it would be impossible for a man vs. woman fight to ever go down in the U.S. Maybe White knew more than we thought.

Didn't Happen


At the last minute the fight was cancelled and left many wondering if it was ever a legitimate contest to begin with. Falcao announced that he suffered an injury in training and was unable to fight, but according to Shooto Brazil President Andre Pederneiras (via MMA Fighting), the fight was still on despite the injury.

Something's Fishy


There were many suspicious things that led up to the contest. Some believe this was a way for Brazil to promote "Lei Maria de Penha," a law that was created to stop violence against women.


However, Falcao said, “I was hired to fight, and I'm going there to fight. My job is to train and fight. This is the first of the many man vs. woman fights that will come in the future. You'll see. This is going to be huge. We're here to shock the world."

item.title: Look Out for These UFC Women in 2014
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
UFC women’s bantamweight champion Ronda Rousey opened doors for women to really become part of the biggest stage in the sport as more fans are tuning in to watch the women spar. Strawweight is the newest weight class to be added to the Ultimate Fighting Championship. Now there will be two weight classes for the top women in the sport to showcase their skills.


Joanne Calderwood


Now fans have their eyes glued to see which females will stand out in MMA for 2014. There are a few to keep your eye on over the next year. Let’s start with Joanne Calderwood (8-0) who is super talented. She is stepping foot in The Ultimate Fighter house for season 20 of the hit reality show. While at Invicta FC 7 she got the call from UFC president Dana White and will be one of 16 women competing for the inaugural 115-pound UFC belt. She is likely to be one of the upcoming stars in the UFC.


Tecia Torres


Tecia Torres (4-0), aka the “Tiny Tornado” offers a a relentless attack of wrestling and powerful striking. At Invicta FC 7, Torres was able to dominate Felice Herrig. Torres is another competitor on season 20 of TUF and those who are discussing the upcoming season view Torres as one of the favorites to come away with the tournament title. Torres deserves to be discussed among the best talents at 115-pounds.


Bec Hyatt


Bec Hyatt (5-3), aka “Rowdy,” she never backs down from a fight. She offered a tough contest against Invicta champ Carla Esparza. Hyatt has the foundation of a rising star that fans will be eager to watch. Hyatt will also be a competitor on season 20 of TUF.


Mizuki Inoue


Mizuki Inoue (7-1) is only 19 years old and is already one of the top strawweights in the world. Under contract with Jewels, we may not get to see her inside of the UFC octagon just yet. Inoue has finished five of her eight opponents by way of submission and she has still yet to reach her full potential.


Miriam Nakamoto


Miriam Nakamoto (2-1) has some of the best Muay Thai in the women’s bantamweight division and can destroy her opponents with her hands, knees and kicks. If Nakamoto can get a win or two under the Invicta banner after her return, there is little doubt that she will get the call to join the UFC.


Rose Namajunas


Rose Namajunas (2-1) has already developed a big fan base thanks to her electrifying fighting style. She showed this earlier this year with a flying armbar victory over Kathina Catron that was one of the best submissions of 2013.  At only 21, Namajunas passion and energy is sure to make her a star.


Holly Holm


Holly Holm (6-0) is the top prospect in women’s mixed martial arts and is an undefeated former pro boxer. Fans want the UFC to sign Holm and bring her in for a title shot against champion Ronda Rousey. Holm has finished five of her six opponents with strikes so she is a force to be reckoned with.

item.title: MMA: You are Only as Good as Your Coach
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
You can only do as good in MMA as your coach, in other words, you need to get a good MMA coach to train you. MMA as a fitness training is gaining recognition these days because of what it does for the overall body. It strengthens and tones the body plus it offers a great cardio workout.


MMA Benefits


The benefits are outstanding and include increasing stamina and strength, improving hand and eye coordination, and developing confidence. There is no better workout than this because it consists of a combination of karate, grappling, wrestling, and boxing.
So, in order to reap the most benefits, it is essential to get a good MMA coach since they cannot teach you what they don’t know themselves. Coaches must be well versed in precise timing, positioning and the techniques used on the opponent during the competition. Fighters are able to control the range and pace of a fight during the competition.


MMA Develops Skill


As MMA becomes more and more popular the development of skills that allow a more dynamic style of competition become more popular as well.  This all falls on the shoulders of the MMA coach who has the job of helping the fighter gain by adjusting the fighting posture to that makes it easier to slump or spread out, to work on takedowns and to understand about the grips and positions.


MMA Coaches


Coaches must spend many hours with a fighter to prepare him or her for the cage. This makes it important to also find a coach that can self sacrifice what is necessary to engage the fighter. There are many coaches and many classes to choose from. It is important to spend the time to find the right coach because anything else and settling for less is only serving a huge injustice to the sport.

item.title: MMAjunkies 2013 Fighter of the Year: Chris Weidman
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
It may come as a surprise that the final results of the MMAjunkie’s 2013 Fighter of the Year winner is Chris Weidman.  The surprise could be since he did not compete at all for the first half of the year and he only had one opponent in the second half.


While this is all true, consider this, the one person he did fight, twice in the second half, he defeated. His opponent was none other than the UFC middleweight great Anderson Silva, a true MMA legend and likely the greatest MMA contender of all time.


Weidman has had to do some treading through tough waters in his time. Weidman ended 2012 injured, his home was destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, his career was on hold. He underwent shoulder surgery in late November 2012 and began his 2013 still in recovery, which is why he was out of commission the first half of 2012.


Weidman’s first fight at UFC 162 saw a cocky Silva get knocked out, unexpectedly. The second fight ended with Silva screaming in agony on the mat with a mangled leg after Weidman checked a second-round leg kick.


Those two wins together cemented Weidman as the legitimate UFC middleweight champ and tossed Silva to the side from a spot that he had reigned at for so long. That alone won Weidman the 2013’s Fighter of the Year with less than 13 minutes in the cage.

 

Runner-up: Vitor Belfort


Perhaps, not so surprising, the runner up is Vitor Belfort based on his sheer dominance. Belfort fought Michael Bisping, Luke Rockhold, and Dan Henderson and he knocked them all out, with devastating displays of power, speed and skill.
So, many may wonder why this wasn’t enough to seal the win. It could be that he had some controversy over use of testosterone-replacement therapy.  Regardless, Belfort did have a great year.


Here is the way the voting came down:
• Chris Weidman (37%)
• Vitor Belfort (24%)
• Demetrious Johnson (14%)
• Urijah Faber (9%)
• Cain Velasquez (8%)
• Travis Browne (5%)
• Write-in Georges St-Pierre (1%)
• Write-in Ronda Rousey (1%)
• Write-in Jon Jones (1%)

item.title: From Beauty Pageants to MMA: Welcome 2012 Miss United States Pageant Winner
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
The 2012 Miss United States pageant winner, Whitney Miller, has decided to take up Brazilian jiu-jitsu and already has her first tournament under her belt where she placed second. BTW…this was after only three months of training. Impressive Whitney!


Last month, Miller was present to watch UFC 168 to watch Ronda Rousey defend her women’s bantamweight title against Miesha Tate in Las Vegas. This got Miller thinking; maybe she would make the transition into MMA. She told FOX Sports, “It’s been talked about. It’s a definite possibility.”
24 year old Miller has always competed in sports since she was a girl – from soccer to track and field to professional wake surfing. She saw BJJ as “one of the hardest things to do” and wanted the challenge. Miller said, “I’m totally addicted to it now. I can’t stop.”


Miller is a Texas native and she does Brazilian jiu-jitsu four times a week and wants to add a fifth day. Miller has also taken classes in boxing and kickboxing. She still does modeling, but says her pageant days are over because she is on a new journey now.


Only six months into training, Miller is focused on her black belt in BJJ and knows she has a long way to go.  But she did excel in her first tournament against women who were more experienced. One of Miller’s coaches at Austin Kickboxing, Tessa Simpson, said she was surprised at how strong Miller is and how good of a natural wrestling base she had. “I think she’s gonna do well going forward with competing, just adding that technique,” Simpson said. “She’s improving very quickly.


Miller would like to break down the beauty queen stereotypes and act as a role model for younger girls. She plans on keeping people updated with her journey on YouTube. Miller said, “You can do it all. Women see this combative sport as solely masculine, very manly. It is, but that doesn’t mean you can’t get in there and kick some ass, too.”


Miller won’t be in the UFC for a while though. She needs more experience and she is only weighing in at 105 pounds and the UFC has women’s divisions at 135 pounds and just added one at 115.


About watching the Rousey/Tate fight, Miller said, “I thought it was awesome. They’re both absolutely beautiful and completely talented. … I want to let that pageant side down, not worry about what I’m looking like. As soon as you worry about what you’re looking like in jiu-jitsu, you get choked out. Or in MMA, you’re getting knocked out.”

item.title: MMA: Now More of a Household Name
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
There are a lot of people who have been enjoying some pretty strenuous workouts but then something happens and they hit a plateau. Unsure of what to do next, many are turning to MMA routines that teach grappling, striking, and how to execute takedowns. MMA or mixed martial arts is the fast-growing combat sport popularized by the Ultimate Fighting Championship.


MMA utilizes Brazilian jiu-jitsu, wrestling, boxing and other fighting styles but in addition to using mixed martial arts solely for fighting many people are just using it to get and stay fit. MMA enthusiasts are coming in all ages and physiques. It has become quite common to find the classes at local gyms populated by women and even children.


MMA has been able to do a really good job of erasing the stigma around the sport that there's going to be blood everywhere. The majority of people joining (the classes) have no intention of getting into a fight. They want to cut weight like a fighter, according to one MMA coordinator.
Boxing and kickboxing are not new to the fitness arena and have been often used for a fast-paced cardio workout. As MMA gets more popular the fitness trend is expanding to offer Tabata, P90X and Insanity. In fact, MMA training is becoming offered at many fitness gyms. The gyms include thick floor mats, padded walls, speed bags and cage-like fences.


For kids, MMA is pushing karate and taekwondo off into a corner. And, there are more women turning to MMA than ever before. Women like it because the lessons are controlled and it focuses heavily on self-defense and technique. It takes women no time before they are bobbing and weaving, grappling, and learning how to fall correctly. Women notice the difference in their core and in flexibility.


MMA offers a win win workout for everyone and also incorporates self defense in it too. It is no wonder that the numbers continue to soar.

item.title: Kick Back at Oceanside
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
Kick Back at Oceanside

Join us at the Compound and take part in the response to the rise of assaults on women.

 

At the Compound, our philosophy is to hope for the best and plan for the worst.  There is one sure way to reduce the number of women that are assaulted annually in the U.S. and that is to teach them how to defend themselves by empowering them.

 

The statistics are mind blowing, really. Over 22 million women in the United States have been raped in their lifetime. 18.3% of women in the United States have survived a completed or attempted rape. Of the 18.3% of women who have survived rape or attempted rape, 12.3% were younger than age 12 when they were first raped, and 29.9% were between the ages of 11 and 17. Every two minutes, somewhere in America, someone is sexually assaulted.

 

This is where we come in…the Compound will teach females of all ages a wide range of techniques and prevention methods, from strategies to punches and everything in between. These techniques can be learned by anyone and ensure that no woman is ever again left exposed and vulnerable.

Come and learn how to protect yourself by some of the finest MMA instructors:

Anthony Formosa: Juijitsu Instructor

Misha Nassiri: Professional Fighter

Crystal Garcia: Fitness Instructor

SC Martines: XFS Amateur Champion

 

The Event: Kick Back at Oceanside

(Women’s Self Defense Seminar)

When: Saturday, Feb 22

Where: 8303 Oceanic Dr.

Oceanside, CA 92056

For more info: (760)966-0776
