item.title: MMA Enhances a Variety of Careers
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
MMA sure has come a long way since just being associated with bulked up men sparring in the cage for entertainment purposes. Women have now become a very big part of what MMA now represents. There have been numerous benefits discovered for youths, many health benefits, to stay fit, and for self defense purposes. In many cases, MMA can also save a person’s life.

 

Police & Law Enforcements

 

There are a few very high risk professions that could very much gain from the benefits that MMA offers, especially when there is the risk of hand-to-hand combat. People such as police and others in law enforcement may have rigorous training to endure but MMA skills will complement and enhance any training, making the job even easier.

 

Bouncers & Bodyguards

 

Imagine the job of a bouncer that works in an environment that is conducive to fights and physical altercations and very often these people can seem intimidating and a lot bigger. Knowing MMA makes size and strength irrelevant. Knowing MMA also means that even if weapons are involved the person with the MMA skills still has the advantage. The same holds true for bodyguards.  

 

Military & Secret Service

 

There are major advantages for anyone involved in the military to know different aspects of combat. In fact, many of the great MMA fighters do have military backgrounds, including Randy Couture, Tim Kennedy and Brian Stann. Secret service should also have MMA training. But, in essence, MMA has vast and diverse advantages to all who study it.  

 

MMA brings a sense of community to the table but it also is a confidence builder, offers massive self discipline, improves levels of fitness, and instills a tranquil mind and spirit, and has amazing self defense benefits preparing for even the most dangerous situations.

item.title: Losing Just Isnt an Option for MMA Contenders
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
The old cliché, you win some and you lose some is not one of the sayings that MMA has chosen to adopt. A better saying might be, “Winning isn't everything; it’s the only thing.” That saying holds a lot of weight within MMA, which is a competition sport and according to an article in The Bleacher Report, history is unkind to those who would accept second best. The value of losing is perhaps most often overlooked variable.

 

Losing is a Learned Skill

 

MMA competition is a high level competition sport and lying down simply is not an option. Losing is a process that actually has to be taught and acquired for MMA competitors. Dr. Michael Gervais, director of High Performance Psychology at DISC Sports and Spine Center said, “Pain is required to help increase the appetite to grow and to actually take action towards it. Oftentimes, losing is painful, and because of that it can help sharpen the intensity and the learning curve and the appetite to learn.”

 

Not Taking Losing Lightly

 

MMA fighters see losing as very personal and do not take lightly to losing in front of an audience of millions. Dr. Ted Butryn points out that the dynamics of a fight are universally understood. He says, “If you’re a football lineman, the coach knows if you missed a block, but the world doesn’t know unless you really mess up. But when you’re out there by yourself in the cage, you’re naked. Everyone knows you got beat up. It’s obvious even to people who don’t know anything about the sport.”

 

There is no other sports loss that sting quite as bad as one in MMA. The physical and emotional toll drives the loss right up to the top. Dr. Gervais said, “There’s an ancient tone to combat sports. It is a test of a man’s hands and head, and that’s all that’s left in an environment where most people are looking to escape. These incredible modern day gladiators are embracing that moment and able to stand in an environment that most people shudder from. Because of that, the intimacy of the exposure, what most people are afraid of, which is looking bad publicly and real physical harm, these men and women are clearly engaging in a deeper level of competition.”

 

Fighter Fears

 

There is a psychological value that defines MMA fears, fear of not being good enough, fear of looking bad, the fear of social rejection, and the fear of danger. These are the elements that have to be embraced so the athlete can look past them and focus on what is under their own control.

 

Each MMA competitor is associated with their own success. Dr. Gervais said, “If our self-worth is defined by the outcome or success in our sport, when we enter the cage that means 100 percent of our identity is at stake. And that’s too big of a risk to take, so the athlete tends to tighten up, rather than get into an ideal mind-set.”

 

It Ends the Way it Ends

 

This is why sports psychologists work with fighters so they don’t place too much emphasis on the outcome. They want them to the focus should be on controlling those elements that are within control. Dr. Gervais concludes, “When the emphasis is placed at a very high level on the outcome and misses the importance of refining the process and refining the craft over time, a loss or a win can become skewed. Another way of understanding it is that, when we work with athletes, what we want to do is be able to balance the importance of mastering the craft over time to put in perspective the value of a win and a loss.”

item.title: There is a Long History Behind What MMA is Today
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) has a long and rich history behind it, which most are unaware of. Before weapons came about, civilizations had to rely on combat sports in order to survive. MMA was often used as a way to entertain during peace time while also staying fit for when war broke out. As weapons began to evolve, it was the Western countries that were quick to replace martial arts with weapons and firearms.

 

 

MMA Ancient Egypt

 

 

Tracing back to 3,000 B.C, the Egyptian pyramids were found to have hieroglyphic inscriptions engraved in them that contained fighting and practicing martial arts. In tombs along the Nile River the same inscriptions have been found. Around 700 B.C., the Greeks were using wrestling, boxing and other combat sports as part of the Olympiads.

 

 

MMA Ancient China

 

 

Pankration, which is a martial sport that combined boxing and wrestling techniques, was practiced by Roman gladiators. Martial arts were practiced in China as far back as 200 B.C. Muay, an ancient form of martial arts, were used for warfare and later became a spectator sport in Thailand. Muay contests became an important part of local festivals and celebrations, and were used as entertainment for kings. Today, this sport continues as the national sport of Thailand and it has very few rules.

 

 

MMA Phillipines

 

 

In the Philippines, several forms of martial arts and combat sports have used such as boxing, grappling, foot fighting, and weapon- based arts. Much later, around the 1930’s, the Filipinos tried to tame their methods of dueling by using full-contact bouts where the combatants used rattan sticks. This form of fighting very much resembled what we know today as MMA. 

 

 

MMA Japan

 

 

Japanese Shooto was created by a famous Japanese pro wrestler in 1983-1984. It is a combination of Sambo, Catch-As-Catch-Can Wrestling, Muay Thai, Judo and Jiu Jitsu. The hallmark striking and grappling resemble modern MMA. This was just about a decade before the first UFC and was a originator to the Pride Fighting Championships (Pride FC). The Tokyo Dome was home to the Pride FC’s first event in 1997. It later went on to become one of the world’s most popular MMA organizations in the world for about ten years.

 

Japan has a long history in MMA but in the early 1900’s, MMA fighting, which featured jujutsu masters versus boxing practitioners was extremely popular throughout Japan, but also in Europe and Brazil as well, according to an article in OC Kickboxing. Japan would send their best fighters overseas to compete in these events. But, the U.S. also had a long tradition of martial arts and combat sports dating back to the very beginning.

 

 

MMA USA

 

 

It is interesting to note that, the first president of the United States, George Washington, enjoyed Irish Collar and Elbow Wrestling. He wasn’t alone though as Abraham Lincoln and Teddy Roosevelt also were known to partake in American folk wrestling styles. In the early 1700’s, American street-fight-style matches allowed boxing, grappling, eye gouging, groin strikes, hair pulling. After one was knocked out, a winner could be declared. This became known as boxing.

 

The late 60’s and early 70’s were the Bruce Lee era where Kung Fu, Boxing, Muay Thai, Wrestling, and Jiu Jitsu made up mixed martial arts. This may have been the greatest single contributor to modern MMA. Dana White, of the UFC, credited Bruce Lee as the first to practice MMA in America.

 

 

MMA Brazil

 

 

Brazil was where No Holds Barred matches began. In the early 1900’s, Mitsuyo Maeda, a Judo champion, emigrated from Japan to Brazil where he started a Japanese colony. There, he befriended Gastão Gracie and began to teach Gastão’s son, Carlos Gracie the art of Judo. Later, in 1925 Carlos and his brother Helio opened a Jiu Jitsu school in Rio de Janeiro, issued an “open challenge”, and began to take on all comers in more than 1,000 freestyle Vale Tudo matches.

  

Practitioners of various different martial art styles showed up to compete. This became so popular that they were held in large soccer stadiums and became the second largest spectator sport in terms of ticket sales in Brazil. In the early 1980’s, Helio Gracie’s eldest son, Rorion Gracie moved to the United States where he and his brothers introduced “Gracie Challenge.”

 

$100,000 was offered to anyone who could defeat Gracie or one of his brothers in a Vale Tudo style match. The Gracies began making a name for themselves in the world of American martial arts. Eventually, along with Art Davie and Bob Meyrowitz created “The Ultimate Fighting Championship”, a “no holds barred” event for pay-per-view television.

 

This was the beginning of the UFC that we know today but it wasn’t without flaws. Because there were no rules the sport was quite brutal and drew a lot of criticism, eventually becoming outlawed and being dropped from most cable networks. Zuffa LLC eventually bought the UFC for $2,000,000 and set up new rules.

 

They secured Nevada Athletic Commission sanctioning in 2001 and landed it back on pay-per-view television. This is when the MMA grew fast and emerged into the mainstream. By 2006, MMA’s annual pay-per-view revenue exceeded that of Pro Boxing and the WWE. The rest is just history.

item.title: MMA rallies to turn bully victims into bully victors
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
National Bully Day

 

 

MMA is proven to be an excellent tool for countering bullying. While it is Australia that actually has declared National Day of Action Against Bullying and Violence, the message is being heard loud and clear here too. One of the toughest men in the world, UFC fighter BJ Penn, will be spreading the word about bullying. Penn was the first non-Brazilian native to win gold in the black belt category at the World Jiu Jitsu Championships. He is the former UFC Lightweight Champion and the former UFC Welterweight Champion, and he holds a straightforward approach to bullying, according to an article in the Daily Telegraph.

 

Penn said, “It’s great to be involved with an event that has a positive message like this. I think people need to be aware that bullying occurs every day and everywhere and is not limited to any particular age or economic class. We need to get the message out that bullying is not OK and will not be tolerated in our society.” To support the message, several organizations are partnering to raise awareness and funds for the anti-bullying charity Bully Zero. National Day of Action against Bullying and Violence is Friday March 21, 2014.

 

The message is that MMA stands for respect, honor, discipline, courage, strength and having fun. Many of the MMA elite are joining in on the cause and many have been bullied in the past. They want people to know that bullying is never acceptable. Not only does MMA teach people to defend themselves it also offers the discipline and focus needed to deal with the stresses of everyday life.

 

 

 

How MMA transforms

 

 

MMA is a combination of boxing, wrestling and all forms of martial arts. MMA is highly regulated and there are rules in place to protect the fighters. Bullying in school and online has become more of a worry over the past few years. Bullies target kids that lack confidence that they feel would make an easy mark. These are the kids that lack confidence on how to deal with the situation.MMA teaches kids how to daunt and diffuse these situations.

 

 

 

Bullying takes a toll

 

 

Bullying takes a heavy toll on kids that are the victims. These kids withdraw, digress, are depressed, have academic problems at school, always feel ill, and believe they are dumb losers.  If you are concerned your child is a victim of bullying talk with them to see what’s going on and what can be done. If your child is being bullied consider MMA for them. It does not promote confrontation but instead teaches confidence, the ability to stay confident and deal with any situation no matter how challenging, how to resolve conflict, and how to defend themselves.

 

 

The benefits

 

 

The benefits are countless. Your child will find a newfound sense of self confidence, an improved attitude, how to overcome adversity, how to deal with difficult situations, how to be a leader, enhanced strength and flexibility, and improved fitness. Plus, they will meet new friends and have great fun!

item.title: Lingerie Fighting Championship set to make first pay-per-view debut
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
Surely, you have heard of the LFC, which is a combination of UFC and WWE that is more entertaining and more exaggerated, primarily for entertainment purposes. The matches are not pre-determined and the women are wearing very little but they are fighting. The fighting is different in the sense that there are no knockouts and most of the tussle takes place on the ground.

 

When it airs

 

On April 11(9 p.m. ET) the Lingerie Fighting Championship will make its pay-per-view debut. MMA's most controversial league" is prerecorded but will air on that date. It is expected that the Lingerie Fighting Championships will steer up controversy and may not be received well by the female MMA professionals.

 

Not mixed martial arts

 

LFC is clearly not mixed martial arts and that is apparent. It is there to tease and titillate the guys who love watching less than half dressed women roll around on the floor in provocative positions. It's like a semi-real catfight in a cage. LFC president Roni Taylor says she got the idea when she was just a fan at an MMA show. The two ring girls got into a physical altercation and the crowd was more into that than whatever was going on in the cage.

 

Taylor says that she doesn’t see what the big deal is as it is not much different from how women's MMA is promoted. Taylor said that UFC women's bantamweight champion Ronda Rousey is "already objectified" because of photo shoots she has done, like the ESPN The Magazine Body Issue in which she appeared artistically naked. Taylor says she has just taken it to the next level.

 

 

Is it more than soft core porn?

Taylor said every girl in the organization has an athletic background and she helps train them in actual MMA. Taylor said, "Girls are wearing everything from bikinis to lingerie to corsets," Taylor said. "Are we showing more than any other girl that's fighting [in MMA]? No, it's just a different outfit." Taylor admits that she doesn’t really care what people call this and says, “Call it a pro wrestling/MMA hybrid or watered-down soft-core porn.” Whatever it is, she says there is a demand for it and there is plenty of entertainment value.

item.title: Fallon Fox: MMAs first transgender in the cage
item.dc:creator: EMH
item.content:encoded:
MMA has undoubtedly captured the heart of America. Men, women, and kids alike love MMA so it should not come as such a surprise that the transgender population wants in too. Currently, there is only one transgender professional MMA fighter, Fallon Fox. The place is Miami, the time is October when swiftly disrobes in front of about a hundred MMA fans down to a black string bikini with a big affliction logo on the ass.  

The issue of gender

38 year old Fox is five foot six inches and weighs in at about 145 pounds and not many fighters will agree to fight her. Fox trains diligently training five hours a day, six days a week. Fox, who was born male said, “MMA is the most dangerous sport there is for a transgender, with all the body contact, I know that. But it just turned out that I was good at it, you know? You pursue what you're good at.... I realize that it's kind of amazing that I hit girls. You're brought up not to hit girls, that it's the worst sin, and that's what I do. But you know, gender is the last thing I think about when I'm fighting. It's the one situation where I don't think of gender at all.”

Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel 

Fallon Fox is a lesbian transgender athlete who fights women in a cage and fathered a daughter and served as a man in the Navy. Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel will air a segment on Fallon Fox during their episode on Tuesday and talk about coming out as a transgender in March 2013. Most recently, Fox won her first professional match in her home town of Chicago. She had massive support. Fox said, "To be in the city where I started, the city that welcomed me with open arms since the moment I first moved here, was an amazing experience. People came from all over the area to view some amazing fights and to see me. And they cheered me on. I love my town."

 

The episode of Real Sports premieres April 22 and will run for the following few weeks. Fallon Fox is now the most prominent transgender athlete in professional sports and a trailblazer for the transgender community. The MMA community is not very accepting of Fox, mainly because they believe her male attributes provide an unfair advantage.
